prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We observed SFO82 in CO(J=1-0) with NANTEN2 and Mopra telescope, and identified three dense filamentary clouds(A,B, and C) associated with this source and found that it is distributed along the direction to exciting cluster, NGC6231. This structure and its velocity field correspond well with the result obtained from theoretical work of Bisabs et al.2011,2014. The obseravtion area is defined to cover clump A, and CO(J=1-0) is the best for observation line to decompose into fine structures. C18O emission intensity with Mopra is about 2.5K, and the velocity dispersion 1.6km/s, so the desired sensitivity is 0.5K for 0.16km/s velocity resolution.

We observed SFO82 in CO(J=1-0) with NANTEN2 and Mopra telescope, and identified three dense filamentary clouds(A,B, and C) associated with this source and found that it is distributed along the direction to exciting cluster, NGC6231. This structure and its velocity field correspond well with the result obtained from theoretical work of Bisabs et al.2011,2014. The obseravtion area is defined to cover clump B, and CO(J=1-0) is the best for observation line to decompose into fine structures. C18O emission intensity with Mopra is about 4.7K, and the velocity dispersion 1.2km/s, so the desired sensitivity is 0.9K for 0.16km/s velocity resolution.

We observed SFO82 in CO(J=1-0) with NANTEN2 and Mopra telescope, and identified three dense filamentary clouds(A,B, and C) associated with this source and found that it is distributed along the direction to exciting cluster, NGC6231. This structure and its velocity field correspond well with the result obtained from theoretical work of Bisabs et al.2011,2014. The obseravtion area is defined to cover clump C, and CO(J=1-0) is the best for observation line to decompose into fine structures. C18O emission intensity with Mopra is about 3.0K, and the velocity dispersion 1.5km/s, so the desired sensitivity is 0.6K for 0.16km/s velocity resolution.

We observed SFO82 in CO(J=1-0) with NANTEN2 and Mopra telescope, and identified three dense filamentary clouds(A,B, and C) associated with this source and found that it is distributed along the direction to exciting cluster, NGC6231. This structure and its velocity field correspond well with the result obtained from theoretical work of Bisabs et al.2011,2014. The obseravtion area is defined to cover clump D, and CO(J=1-0) is the best for observation line to decompose into fine structures. C18O emission intensity with Mopra is about 1.5K, and the velocity dispersion 0.6km/s, so the desired sensitivity is 0.3K for 0.16km/s velocity resolution.

We observed SFO82 in CO(J=1-0) with NANTEN2 and Mopra telescope, and identified three dense filamentary clouds(A,B, and C) associated with this source and found that it is distributed along the direction to exciting cluster, NGC6231. This structure and its velocity field correspond well with the result obtained from theoretical work of Bisabs et al.2011,2014. The obseravtion area is defined to cover clump E, and CO(J=1-0) is the best for observation line to decompose into fine structures. C18O emission intensity with Mopra is about 1.6K, and the velocity dispersion 1.2km/s, so the desired sensitivity is 0.32K for 0.16km/s velocity resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Bright-Rimmed Clouds (BRCs) embedded in HII regions are one of the most promising objects, where we are able to study into detail the physical processes of triggered star formation. In this proposal we focus on the largest BRC SFO82 excited by a rich cluster NGC6231. By the recent CO observations with Mopra, we have found that the dense C18O gas forms a thin filament pointing toward the exciting cluster. In the filament several young infrared stars are embedded, indicating triggered star formation. The gas compression in BRCs is believed to be due to Radiation Driven Implosion (RDI) which efficiently compresses the gas three dimensionally. Recent numerical simulations of RDI have successfully reproduced formation of such a filament, demonstrating a remarkable correspondence with the observations (Bisbas et al. 2011). We propose to use ALMA to obtain high resolution images of the molecular gas toward the filament in 13CO, C18O and other lines in band3 and make a detailed comparison with the numerical simulations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: PI Fukui "Probing filamentary sub-structure and triggered star formation in bright rimmed clouds"
